chunks.en: Watched Nezha 2 last night, sharing my thoughts
Overall, it's passable, with high marks for BGM and special effects. The plot is average, and the whole movie relies on being "reckless" to drive the plot and create conflict.
Some serious scenes are forced to include "humorous elements", but after all, it's the Spring Festival season, so this can be understood.
It's a pity that there's no other strong competitor, benefiting from the timing.
Thinking back on the movies I've watched in the past few years (not many): Oppenheimer, Flying Life 2, Suzume.
Nezha 2 is somewhat similar to Suzume, both having plots that feel far-fetched.
Personal viewing ranking: Oppenheimer > Nezha 2 > Suzume > Flying Life 2.
Oppenheimer gave me goosebumps in the cinema, while the others have some flaws, more or less.

Jiaozi (the director) mentioned in an interview that the plot was simplified for all age groups. If it were like the plot of Japanese anime such as Suzume, it might not even surpass the previous film's box office in China.
The domestic market is like this, picking the best among the worst. In my opinion, it's a 7.5-point movie.
Nezha 2 is originally a Lunar New Year film, with good special effects and a coherent and relatively complete plot.
To be honest, watching Oppenheimer in the cinema made me want to sleep. I kept thinking, is this also considered persecution?
The script is bad, portraying Nezha as reckless and unthinking, with a bunch of tired Douyin jokes.
Suzume > Oppenheimer > Nezha 2 > Flying Life 2

@free9fw #2 I personally don't think Suzume is good, the plot feels far-fetched, and the protagonist is too focused on romance, but the BGM is really great. I've been listening to all of Suzume's BGM at work for a long time, and it's very ethereal.
I agree, the plot feels far-fetched, like the story is there to serve a conclusion.

Haven't watched Nezha 2 yet. Nezha 1 had a good reputation at the time. I followed and watched it twice. The production was very sophisticated, but the plot felt a bit clichÃ©, and I always felt that the Nezha in it was a bit like the Red Guards...
But, in the end, the fact that it can be produced so well is very encouraging.

@LieEar #20 @gransh #37 @keengrass #39 @lada05 #44 What you're saying is actually the same thing: the field of art has in fact regressed to a feudal society. It's not just that the feudal production relations within the industry have hindered the quality of films, but also that those who control resources and discourse power (directors, producers, investors, etc.) completely represent the remnants of feudalism and the reactionaries. In terms of funds, they are laundering money, sucking the audience's wallets dry, and so forth; in terms of films, they are distorting the few remaining noble qualities and using the so-called "artistic adaptation" as a smokescreen. In reality, they are distorting the facts, slandering the masses, and forcing the audience to eat shit with both hands.

Under this kind of environment, a few directors (and film crews) who are truly dedicated to making films have finally emerged. Even if the films that come out have flaws, it's a real issue of skill, not a deliberate attempt to feed the audience shit. Isn't this worthy of a high box office?
Moreover, the quality of these films themselves is also good; 8.5 out of 10 is fine, and some can even aim for 9 points.
